column7: General Information
column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column7: ASX stands for Australian Securities Exchange. It was created by the merger of the Australian Stock Exchange and the Sydney Futures Exchange in July 2006 and is one of the world's top-10 listed exchange groups measured by market capitalisation.

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: ASX Limited, ASX Operations Pty Limited, ASX Clearing Corporation Limited, ASX Settlement Corporation Limited, ASX Settlement Pty Limited, Austraclear Limited, Australian Securities Exchange Limited

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: financial year ended 30 June 2023.

ASX has appointed PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) as its external auditor. The appointment was approved by shareholders at the 2008 AGM. The most recent change of lead audit partner took place in FY19, and the rotation of a new lead partner will occur for FY24.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: ASX operates a significant part of the infrastructure that supports Australia and New Zealand's financial markets. ASX is a multi-asset class and integrated exchange group. The Group operates cash equities and derivatives markets, providing a complete service offering across listings, trading, clearing, settlement, registry, and information and technical services.
Headcount at period end: 1,050
Total contractors: 136 people.

The ASX Board currently comprises nine directors following the retirement of Peter Marriott from the ASX Board. It includes eight independent non-executive directors and one executive director, being the CEO.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: The ASX and CS Boards have formalised the appointment process for non-executive directors. Where an ASX Group Board decides to commence a new director selection process, the Nomination Committee is responsible for, amongst other matters, making recommendations in respect of the recruitment process, the description of the skills, experience, diversity, independence, and other attributes sought for in prospective candidates, identifying and evaluating candidates and recommending to the Board suitable nominees for appointment as a director. The ASX and CS Boards must undertake comprehensive reference checks before appointing a new director to verify the director's skills, experience, fame, and character, including education, employment, character, criminal history, and bankruptcy checks. Every director's proposed appointment to an ASX Group Board requires a statutory 'fit and proper' assessment due to their involvement with market licensees and/ or CS facilities.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Damian Roche was elected ASX's Chair in April 2021 and has served as a director since August 2014. He is Chair of the Nomination Committee and has been a member of the Audit and Risk Committee and the People and Culture Committee since 21 April 2021.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The ASX Board and its committees periodically review ASX's corporate governance arrangements and practices to ensure they continue to be aligned with regulatory requirements, developments in recommended corporate governance practices, stakeholder expectations, and ASX's strategic objectives. Throughout the financial year ended 30 June 2023, ASX's corporate governance arrangements followed the fourth edition of the ASX Corporate Governance Council's corporate governance principles and recommendations.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: The Board governance layer focuses on the role and responsibilities of the ASX Group Boards and Board Committees. The Management governance layer focuses on the role and responsibilities of the Managing Director, Chief Executive Officer (CEO), and Group Executives. The people governance layer focuses on our people's responsibility to adhere to the ASX Values and the standards of behaviour set out in the ASX Code of Conduct and ASX policies and procedures.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: The ASX Board's responsibilities include approving the ASX Group's values, Code of conduct, and key governance policies, defining the ASX Group's strategic objectives, approving the annual budget and financial plans, setting ASX's risk strategy and risk appetite, and appointing, replacing and assessing the performance of the CEO. The ASX Board oversees the ASX Group's performance and progress against strategic objectives, including consistency with ASX's risk management strategy and risk appetite.

ASX and CS Directors must disclose all interests that may conflict with their duties as a Director. A register of Directors' interests is included in the papers for each Board meeting, and a register of Committee members' interests is provided for all Committee meetings. Suppose a Director has a material personal interest in a matter being considered by a Board or Committee. In that case, they must not be present during the consideration of that matter or vote on it unless approved by other Directors with no material personal interest.

Questions to the ASX Chair, Managing Director and CEO, or auditor Financial report These may be emailed to company.secretariat@asx.com.au Or mailed to ASX's registered office 1, marked to the attention of the Company Secretary.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: The ASX Board comprises experienced business leaders with various professional backgrounds who collectively have extensive experience in the skill categories the Board has identified as necessary to enable the Board to discharge its responsibilities effectively. The ASX Board has developed a Board Skills Matrix to capture the current mix of skills, experience and diversity. The Board reviews the Skills Matrix annually to ensure that the mix of skills on the Board remains appropriate and to inform director professional development and board succession planning.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column7: By its Charter, the ASX Board assesses its performance, the performance of its Committees and the performance of individual directors annually. The reviews are conducted to help ensure the Boards operate effectively and efficiently. The ASX Board considers the performance review results when recommending a Director's re-election to shareholders.

column13: ASX uplifts our remuneration governance framework. It is to ensure appropriate remuneration outcomes, including implementing a new accountability framework and reviewing our Remuneration Adjustments Policy.
column20: Remuneration governance framework, Accountability framework, Remuneration Adjustments Policy

column7: The aggregate amount paid to non-executive directors is approved by shareholders at the AGM. The maximum aggregate amount for FY23 that may be paid to all ASX non-executive directors in their capacity as members of the ASX Limited Board and its committees and as non-executive directors of subsidiary boards is $3.5 million.

ASX's Board and management are committed to ASX's long-term sustainability. Long-term sustainability is essential to achieving ASX's vision to be the market's choice, inspiring confidence and trust. This report outlines ASX's approach to sustainability, targets, activities and performance in FY23.

ASX remains committed to promoting gender diversity within the organisation. There is a female representation target of 45% of the total headcount by FY25. It is supported by gender-neutral hiring, promotion, and development policies.
ASX is committed to ensuring its governance arrangements are commensurate with the nature and scope of its operations

ASX is committed to taking appropriate action when a complaint is raised, and an investigation may follow in line with ASX complaint handling procedures. Any substantiated breach of the ASX Diversity and Inclusion Policy will be dealt with seriously and may result in disciplinary action. Discrimination, harassment, defamation and victimisation will not be tolerated at ASX.

ASX's Code of Conduct, Anti-Bribery and Corruption, and Whistleblower Protection policies set the standards of behaviour expected from our people. These policies apply to directors, employees and contractors. Material breaches of the Code of Conduct, the Anti-Bribery and Corruption Policy, or material incidents reported under the Whistleblower Protection Policy are reported to the Audit and Risk Committee and/or Board.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: ASX's approach is intended to build confidence and trust in our Whistleblower Protection Policy (Policy), processes and procedures. Our Policy provides relevant information to assist you in making whistleblower disclosures. It sets out how ASX protects you from any form of retaliation or victimisation, including termination of employment, harassment and discrimination, when you create a legitimate whistleblowing disclosure by the requirements of this Policy and relevant legislation.
column20: Whistleblower Protection Policy, Whistleblower disclosures, Retaliation protection

column7: On 28 March 2023, ASIC confirmed to ASX that it had commenced an investigation into suspected contraventions of the ASIC Act 2001 and the Corporations Act 2001 about the CHESS replacement program. ASIC is investigating whether ASX Limited, ASX Clear Pty Limited, ASX Settlement Pty Limited and/or their directors and officers breached obligations under the Corporations Act 2001 and the ASIC Act 2001 during the period 28 October 2020 to 28 March 2022 regarding oversight of the program and statements and disclosures made by or on behalf of ASX as to the status of the program. The investigation is ongoing, and ASX is fully cooperating with ASIC.
Federal Labor Business Forum and the Liberal Party Australian Business Network

column13: In FY23, ASX commenced regular pulse surveys to check in on employee wellbeing and seek feedback on actions. This practice will continue in FY24 to ensure employees feel supported through change.
column20: Employee wellbeing, Pulse surveys, Feedback mechanisms

column13: In our FY23 annual survey, we saw engagement increase to 67%, up 3% from the previous year. Our employees tell us that ASX is committed to providing a safe and healthy workplace (91%) where they are proud to work (86%).
column20: Employee engagement survey, Engagement increase, Safe workplace

column7: Following engagement with internal and external stakeholders, ASX has established six key focus areas to support our three sustainability pillars. Three pillars form the foundation of ASX's approach to sustainability: trusted actions, efficient markets, and resilient operations.
Responsible business, People, Risk Management, Market Integrity, Corporate Governance, Innovation
As a founding Champions of Change Coalition (CCC) member, ASX remains committed to ongoing practical actions to improve gender equality.

As part of ASX's ongoing commitment as a Partner Exchange under the UN Sustainable Stock Exchanges (SSE) initiative, ASX confirmed its participation in the UN SSE Net Zero Comment Group aimed at helping the creation of net zero targets for exchanges. It allows ASX to help shape the commitments that exchanges across the globe might make in the future.

ASX remains committed to supporting corporate Australia in achieving its sustainability goals and looks to lead by example. We have earned our target of sourcing 100% renewable electricity 1 this financial year and target net zero Scope 1 and 2 emissions by FY25.
